Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

For authentication, we recommend saving your API key to the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable in your .Renviron file. You can easily edit this file by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  turns = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  seed = NULL,
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "text", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

turns

A list of Turns to start the chat with (i.e., continuing a previous conversation). If not provided, the conversation begins from scratch.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

The API key to use for authentication. You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable.

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call.

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_bedrock(), chat_claude(), chat_cortex_analyst(), chat_databricks(), chat_deepseek(), chat_gemini(), chat_github(), chat_groq(), chat_ollama(), chat_openrouter(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Origin and Package**: 
#>   - **Data Frame**: A base R data structure that has been around since
#> the inception of R.
#>   - **Tibble**: Introduced by the `tibble` package, which is part of 
#> the Tidyverse suite of packages.
#> 
#> - **Printing**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: By default, prints all columns and the data for 
#> the first set of rows; may not always be tidy, particularly with wide 
#> data.
#>   - **Tibble**: Prints a more succinct summary showing the first few 
#> rows and only enough columns that fit on the screen, alongside 
#> information about data types.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: Traditionally, subsetting columns or rows with `[`
#> might result in vectors or change object types unexpectedly.
#>   - **Tibble**: Subsetting retains a tibble structure (maintaining a 
#> dataframe) more consistently, preventing unexpected vector outputs.
#> 
#> - **Column Names**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: Allows non-syntactic column names but with some 
#> limitations in referencing.
#>   - **Tibble**: More flexible with column names, allowing 
#> non-syntactic names without the need to quote them using backticks 
#> within certain functions.
#> 
#> - **Performance**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: Generally more performance-conscious with 
#> operations than tibbles due to additional features in tibbles like 
#> type better consistency.
#>   - **Tibble**: May have slight overhead due to extra features like 
#> better print outputs and more robust handling of data types.
#> 
#> - **Type-Stable**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: Type-stability is less of a focal point, functions
#> may return varied types based on inputs.
#>   - **Tibble**: Emphasizes type-stability; operations using tibbles 
#> tend to be more predictable in terms of result types.
#> 
#> - **Integration with Tidyverse**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: Works with Tidyverse but does not have 
#> enhancements found in tibbles.
#>   - **Tibble**: Integrates seamlessly with Tidyverse tools and 
#> practices, designed to work optimally with other Tidyverse packages.
#> 
#> - **Attributes**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: Supports row names.
#>   - **Tibble**: Generally discourages the use of row names for cleaner
#> data practices, though they can be present if required. 
#> 
#> - **Warnings and Errors**:
#>   - **Data Frame**: Historically less informative when it comes to 
#> operation errors or unexpected behaviors.
#>   - **Tibble**: Provides more informative messages and warnings, 
#> aiding in debugging complex data manipulations.
#> 
#> In summary, tibbles are an enhanced version of data frames, designed 
#> to be more user-friendly and robust, especially within the Tidyverse 
#> ecosystem.

chat$chat("Tell me three funny jokes about statistcians")
#> Sure, here are three jokes about statisticians:
#> 
#> 1. **Confidence Interval**:
#>    - Why don’t statisticians trust their own decisions?
#>    - Because they always think they're within a 95% confidence 
#> interval, and they leave the other 5% to uncertainty!
#> 
#> 2. **Correlation vs. Causation**:
#>    - What’s a statistician’s favorite chat-up line?
#>    - “You must be Pearson, because the correlation between us is 
#> definitely not zero!”
#> 
#> 3. **Normal Distribution**:
#>    - How can you identify a statistician at a party?
#>    - They’ll be the one who won’t stop talking about how normal 
#> everything is!
#> 
#> I hope these bring a smile! Let me know if you want more.
